Over the past few years, Maryland's Nonpoint Source Management Program has been moving from a predominately grants administering program to a multi-disciplinary program providing not only financial assistance, but nonpoint source related policy, technical and educational assistance. Keys to the Program's success rely on creating open partnerships with other nonpoint source entities and developing long and short term goals that will advance the Program in the nonpoint source pollution control arena. Some key programmatic goals for the NPS Program staff are to continue to submit information bi-annually through the Grants Reporting and Tracking System, to submit an annual project report to EPA, to maintain a user friendly webpage, to ensure that Section 319(h) grant projects result in measurable environmental results, and to better educate the public about the causes and remedies of nonpoint source pollution. One of the long-term goals for Maryland's program will be to continue to work closely with EPA and NOAA to evaluate and revise the State's Nonpoint Source Management Plan.      Statewide Implementation    The "statewide focus" listed in Table 6.1, indicates that many programs and practices will be implemented across the state. Examples include regulatory programs and many technical and financial assistance efforts. Regulatory programs, such as the Stormwater Management Program, the Forest Conservation Act and the Water Quality Improvement Act are implemented either through a permit process where the applicant is not authorized to take action until they can ensure that their activities will comply with state/local requirements or the applicant must submit for approval a plan that outlines how he/she will meet the state requirements. A brief overview of several programs is included below to illustrate how Maryland can ensure that the management measures covered under these regulatory programs will be implemented.    Regulatory Programs      Forestry    The Maryland Forest Conservation Act of 1991 (FCA) was enacted to protect the state's forest by making the identification and protection of forests and other sensitive areas an integral part of the site planning process. DNR's Forest Service is responsible for administering this program which is implemented through 60 local authorities with approved FCA Programs.    The Act requires that DNR conduct a review of local forest conservation programs every two years. In the process of conducting the program reviews, staff assess the compliance of local programs with the intent and standards of the FCA and identify any necessary refinements. The Department works with the jurisdiction to further incorporate sensitive area elements into local review procedures as well as the adoption of the Forest Service's tracking and reporting formats. Through this process of collaboration the successful implementation of forestry management measures is ensured.    Developed Lands    MDE is responsible for minimizing the adverse impacts that land development and urbanization have on stormwater runoff characteristics. The Department establishes policies, procedures, standards, and criteria relating to soil erosion and sediment control and stormwater management. In cases where local governments have shown the ability to enforce the provisions of their ordinances they have been delegated erosion and sediment control enforcement authority. MDE is responsible for approving all state and federal erosion and sediment control plans. Under the state's Stormwater Management Program local jurisdictions have enforcement responsibility. The state sets standards and procedures for local governments to follow and oversees their implementation.      State and local regulatory programs track permits for construction activities. MDE is the lead enforcement agency in most cases, the Inspection and Compliance Division is notified when new projects receive a permit. Applicants must notify the permitting jurisdiction ten days before they begin their construction activities. State and local inspectors make routine site visits throughout the construction process and have the authority to issue cease and disist orders if a project violates state regulations, this includes monetary penalties for projects that remain noncompliant.      Agricultural Lands    On May 12, 1998, Maryland's Governor signed and enacted the Water Quality Improvement Act of 1998. The Law provides a framework for a set of regulatory requirements. The regulations are currently being developed by the Maryland Department of Agriculture (MDA) with the assistance of a 35 member Nutrient Advisory Committee.    The most far-reaching requirement of the WQIA is that all agricultural operations with gross annual incomes greater than $2,500 or with more than eight animal units (one animal unit equals 1,000 pounds live weight) must have and implement a nitrogen and phosphorus-based nutrient management   plan. The Act requires that anyone "who, in operating a farm, or uses chemical fertilizer" must have a nitrogen-and-phosphorus based plan by December 31, 2001, and must implement it by December 31, 2002.      Persons using sludge or animal manure must have and implement nitrogen-based plans by the same dates as those using chemical fertilizers. Those using sludge or animal manure have until July 1, 2004, to submit a nitrogen and phosphorus based nutrient management plan, and must implement it by July 1, 2005.    This legislation applies to all farming operations. This includes poultry and livestock operations, vegetable growers, organic producers, nurseries, greenhouses, turf grass producers, and certain horse farms. Regulations also formalize required nutrient management plan content, standards and criteria to be followed in the development of state-approved nutrient management plans.      All nutrient management plans developed are subject to the Act, and all plan revisions must be filed with the Maryland Department of Agriculture. MDA has full authority to determine compliance with the Act and will conduct on-farm evaluations of the implementation of the nutrient management plan.      Cost Share Programs and Alternative Financing Strategies    Maryland also offers a myriad of cost-share programs that are applied statewide (See Chapter 5 - Public Education, Outreach and Assistance Programs). For example, financial and technical assistance is provided to landowners by Soil Conservation Districts, MDA, NRCS and DNR to implement on-the-ground BMPs that treat runoff, buffer sensitive areas, or provide assistance on forestry and wildlife management activities. The Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) has been influential in recruiting enrollment of agricultural land for riparian forest buffers (DNR - Stream ReLeaf Program) and created wetlands.    In addition, MDE offers cost-share assistance that can be used to fund implementation of nonpoint source capital improvements such as stormwater management and stream restoration projects.    The state is also promoting alternative and innovative financing strategies. Financial burdens placed upon local watershed and stormwater management programs have increased dramatically in recent years as a result of a growing list of federal, state and Chesapeake Bay requirements as well as increased citizen demands to improve the quality of streams, lakes and the Bay. Local governments are currently exploring the establishment of "Watershed / Stormwater Utilities" that will develop a dedicated funding source. Modifications to Maryland's stormwater management law were made in 1992 to allow for "Watershed / Stormwater Utilities" to be developed by local governments.    Watershed Based Implementation    The development of the Tributary Strategies, Targeted Watershed Program, Coastal Bays Management Plan, and the various river basin plans has been an effort to more fully address water quality issues at a smaller geographic (i.e., watershed) scale. During the next 15 years, Maryland will continue to implement the recommendations contained in each of our existing strategies and, pursuant to the Clean Water Action Plan, develop new watershed restoration and conservation action strategies. The following section illustrates how some of these watershed plans will be used to ensure implementation of the management measures.         As part of the Tributary Strategies initiative, specific measures of success (i.e., 40%     nutrient reduction goal) were identified and procedures were established so that the State     could track its progress toward accomplishing the goal. Appendix 4 provides an example of     the most recent implementation table.          The Maryland Coastal Bays Management Plan contains information detailing action items,     timetables and implementing authorities. Members of the various committees (Policy,     Implementation, Scientific and Citizens) are charged with ensuring implementation of the     action items. EPA also conducts a biennial review to assess the state's progress.          The Targeted Watersheds Project demonstrates how targeting can be used to focus     implementation of management measures to a smaller geographic scale. The Project's     objective is to demonstrate that improvements in water quality and habitat conditions can     be achieved by coordinating monitoring, pollution control, and restoration programs of     both public and private organizations.      In 1989, four watersheds were targeted because they were threatened by multiple sources of degradation from urbanization or contributed disproportionately high levels of nutrients to the Chesapeake Bay from agricultural nonpoint sources. The project worked with watershed-wide (synoptic) surveys of nutrients and toxics to identify hot spots and source areas and used protocols such as the Stream Corridor Assessment Methodology to locate problem sites. The members of the project developed a suite of methods for targeting and prioritizing restoration activities and have begun to employ better project designs for the project's BMP evaluations. This project has helped refine the delivery and implementation of watershed restoration services. As we take the lessons learned from this study and apply them to other watersheds, it is anticipated that the delivery of services (technical and financial assistance) will greatly improve.        Maryland updates its list of water quality-limited segments     (the "303(d) list") using data from the 305(b) report with other readily     available information from monitoring efforts conducted by federal and local governmental     agencies, as well as by academic and research organizations. Once the waters to be     included on the 303(d) list have been identified, priority categories (High, Medium and     Low) are assigned to each water quality limited segment. These priority rankings, which     take into account the severity of the pollution and uses to be made of the waters, are     used for purposes of resource allocation and scheduling. However, due to variable data     needs and analytical complexity, priority may not translate directly to order of TMDL     completion. Once approved by EPA, the TMDL sets the framework for tailoring additional     controls and institutional procedures for restoring and maintaining water quality     standards.               The Integrated Project Priority System (IPPS) recently     developed by MDE, promotes watershed-based selection of water pollution control projects     that are proposed for funding by the State. It outlines criteria and procedures for     prioritizing projects which is based on the condition of the receiving waterbody. The IPPS     uses the 303(d) list to identify impaired waters, and to select projects with the most     water quality benefits to minimize existing water quality impairments.               MDE is implementing a Watershed-Based Permitting System. To     facilitate this, MDE has developed a watershed cycling framework in which the State is     divided into five regions. Water quality management activities will be cycled through     those regions over a five-year period. This approach allows a significant amount of     resources to be concentrated in 20% of the State at any given time, thereby increasing     both the efficient use of resources and the intensity of water quality   evaluation.     The choice of a five-year cycle is dictated in large part by the requirement of federal     surface water discharge permits, which are reissued.      Progress Evaluation      During the next 15 years, Maryland will continue to evaluate the effectiveness of projects and/or management systems and their progress toward achieving environmental and programmatic goals. Chapter four details how the state currently tracks its implementation activities. In addition, there are:        numerous checks and balances in the regulatory programs     (e.g., biennial reviews of the local Forest Conservation Act Programs and state review of     the Storm Water Management Programs);     a variety of indicators ( See Chapter two - Environmental     Indicators) that have been developed that will enable the state to measure its     performance;     water quality monitoring programs; and     advisory committees (Tributary Teams, Coastal and Watershed     Resources Advisory Committee and State Water Quality Advisory Committee) that evaluate     current activities and make recommendations that will ensure that efficiency and     effectiveness of future programs.      For example,        Maryland's Stormwater Management Program continues to     evolve as issues related to existing and developing land runoff are identified. Increased     emphasis on water quality, resource protection and BMP maintenance costs have all     contributed to basic philosophical changes regarding stormwater management. The Program is     currently in the process of finalizing draft regulations in an effort to incorporate the     significant experiences gained by the State's stormwater community and accommodate much     needed improvements for managing urban runoff. The proposed regulations include     incorporating the new Maryland Stormwater Design Manual by reference and addressing     re-development.      The design standards and environmental incentives presented in the Manual are intended to advance the science of managing stormwater by relying less on singular BMPs for all development projects and more on mimicking existing hydrology through total site design policies. Additionally, the inherent philosophical change should produce smaller less obtrusive facilities that are more aesthetic and less burdensome on those responsible for long term performance.   The adoption of these new regulations will directly ensure and enhance the implementation of management measures related to developed lands. Some of the management measures that will be promoted through the new regulations include: New Development, Watershed Protection, Site Development, and Vegetative Treatment Systems.    The Maryland Stormwater Management Program conducts periodic reviews of the local jurisdictions operating with approved stormwater management authority. Approved jurisdictions have enforcement responsibility. It is through program review and BMP evaluation that Maryland has continued to enhance the Stormwater Management Program.        Tributary Teams have become involved in many policy issues,     providing recommendations on technical, funding, and planning programs. Team comments have     helped win funding, shape policy direction, and set priorities. Teams have addressed:     Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program, Cover Crop Cost Share Program, Blue Ribbon     Citizens Pfiesteria Action Commission, Stream ReLeaf Implementation Plan, Total Daily     Maximum Loads, Youth Environmental Summit, Clean Water Action Plan, Soil Conservation     District Staffing, Rural Legacy, Priority Funding Areas, Environmental Partnership     Agreement, Implementation Tracking, Stormwater Design Manual, and the1997 Nutrient     Re-evaluation. The Tributary Teams provide an important feedback loop to assist state and     local programs in prioritizing approaches taken in the different watersheds.               Under the TMDL process, the watershed cycling strategy     establishes a natural evaluation framework. As the cycle is completed for a given     watershed, field monitoring will be conducted again where it had been conducted five-years     beforehand. This will serve as an opportunity to assess the initial results of the TMDL     and implementation activities.      The state's efforts to track implementation of best management practices, evaluate program efficiency and effectiveness, along with input received from advisory committees and the results of water quality monitoring and assessments   will allow the state to demonstrate progress, to determine if any mid-course corrections are needed or determine if additional management measures may be required.    Finally, the State of Maryland is participating in the first-ever, comprehensive evaluation of the Chesapeake Bay restoration effort  Chesapeake Bay Program 2000 and Beyond . Extensive public input has been solicited, internal assessment of various provisions have been conducted and various long-term scenarios for the Bay's future are underway. The Chesapeake Bay Program will use the results of this broad valuation process to consider those issues which will be included in the new Chesapeake Bay Agreement. Currently, the Draft Agreement includes new goals as well as issue specific processes that will determine when and how these new efforts will be addressed.    Several examples contained in the Draft Agreement are included below:    (1) While each state continues their efforts to achieve and maintain the 40 percent nutrient reduction goal agreed to in 1987, the new draft agreement commits the Chesapeake Bay Program Signatories to work to ensure that by 2010, we can correct all nutrient-related problems in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries sufficient to remove the Bay and the tidal portions of its tributaries from the list of impaired waters under the Clean Water Act. In order to achieve this the following steps will be taken:    â¢By 2001, define the water quality conditions necessary to protect aquatic living resources; and then, assign load reductions for nitrogen and phosphorus to each major tributary;    â¢By 2002, complete a public process to develop and begin implementation of revised Tributary Strategies to achieve and maintain the assigned loading goals; and,    â¢By 2003, the jurisdictions with tidal waters will use their best efforts to adopt new or revised water quality standards consistent with the defined water quality conditions. Once adopted by the jurisdictions, the EPA will work expeditiously to review the new or revised standards, which will then be used as the basis for removing the Bay and its tidal rivers from the list of impaired waters.    (2) By 2010, the Draft Agreement states that the Signatories will correct all sediment-related problems in the Chesapeake Bay and the tidal portion of its tributaries sufficient to remove the Bay and the tidal portions of its tributaries from the list of impaired waters under the Clean Water Act. In order achieve this the following steps will be taken:    â¢Using a process parallel to that established for nutrients, determine the load reductions to achieve the water quality conditions necessary to protect aquatic living resources and assign load reductions for sediment to each major tributary by 2001;    â¢Complete tributary strategies to achieve the reductions by 2002; and    â¢Integrate sediment reductions in order to develop water quality standards for tidal waters by 2003, based upon the defined water quality conditions.    (3) The Draft Agreement states that the Signatories will achieve a net resource gain by restoring 25,000 acres of tidal and non-tidal wetlands by 2010 in the entire Chesapeake Bay Basin. To do this, the Signatories commit to achieve and maintain an average restoration rate of 2,500 acres per year basin wide by 2005 and beyond. The Signatories will evaluate their success in 2005.    (4) Finally, by 2003, the Signatories will ensure that measures are in place to meet the Chesapeake Bay Basin's riparian forest buffer restoration goal of 2,010 miles by 2010 and determine the potential to significantly expand this goal. Wetlands serve to filter and remove many pollutants.  Wetlands can intercept runoff and transform and store NPS pollutants like sediment, nutrients, and certain heavy metals without being degraded. Subsection 319(h)(11) of the Clean  Water Act of 1987 requires each state to report annually on the progress made toward achieving Nonpoint Source (NPS) Management program goals.  This report  summarizes statewide efforts to control and prevent nonpoint source pollution during 2000.  The report contains a description of nonpoint source pollution prevention  and control efforts by pollutant category (agriculture, forestry, developed lands, etc.); a description of  DNR's Watershed Restoration Action Strategy initiative and a  summary of progress made toward achieving Chesapeake Bay Program nutrient reduction goals.         Clean Water Act & Nonpoint Source Pollution            In 1972, Congress enacted the Federal Water Pollution Control Act in response to growing public concern for serious and widespread water pollution.   The 1972 law built upon previous federal water pollution statutes.  In 1977 the act was amended and renamed the Clean Water Act.  Congress amended the  Clean Water Act in 1987 to establish the section 319 Nonpoint Source Management Program.   The Clean Water Act was reauthorized in 1991.  The Clean Water  Act is the primary federal law that protects our nation's waters, including lakes, rivers, aquifers and coastal areas.       The Clean Water Act's primary objective is to restore and maintain the integrity of the nation's waters. This objective translates into two fundamental national goals:         eliminate the discharge of pollutants into the nation's waters, and      achieve water quality levels that are fishable and swimmable.       The Clean Water Act provides a comprehensive framework of standards, technical tools and financial assistance to address the many causes of pollution  and poor water quality, including municipal and industrial wastewater discharges, polluted runoff from urban and rural areas, and habitat destruction.      Water pollution comes from two sources, point source pollution and nonpoint source pollution.  Point source pollution refers to pollution from a specific  point of discharge (e.g. from an industrial or municipal wastewater plant).  Nonpoint source pollution is runoff caused by stormwater (rainfall or snowmelt)  or irrigation water moving over and through the ground. Nonpoint source pollution is the major reason why water quality remains impaired in the State of Maryland.        Maryland's Nonpoint Source Program            Maryland's Nonpoint Source Program evolved out of the Clean Water Act of 1987.  This act contained a new section, Section 319, which established a nationwide  requirement that each state evaluate the nature and extent of its water quality problems caused by nonpoint source pollution and then prepare a management  program for addressing its priority nonpoint source pollution problems.       The Coastal Zone Management Division in the Chesapeake and Coastal Watershed Service of the Department of Natural Resources oversees the implementation of the  Section 319 Nonpoint Source Management Program.   The program is multi-disciplinary providing not only financial assistance, but nonpoint source related policy, technical  and educational assistance. Keys to the Program's success rely on creating open partnerships with other nonpoint source entities and  developing long and short term goals  that will advance the Program in the nonpoint source pollution control arena.  Maryland provides reimbursable grants to state and local governments, non-profit  organizations, and institutions of higher learning  to implement nonpoint source pollution control projects and programs in accordance with Section 319(h) of the CWA.   Some key programmatic goals for the NPS Program staff are to continue to submit an annual project report to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), to maintain a  user friendly webpage, to ensure that Section 319(h) grant projects result in measurable environmental results (MERs), and to better educate the public about the causes  and remedies of nonpoint source pollution.   Detailed 319(h) project information, including project load reduction estimates are reported bi-annually in EPA's Grant  Reporting & Tracking System.         Regional and State Nonpoint Source Funding            Nationally as of FFY2000, Congress has appropriate over $1 billion to fight nonpoint source pollution.  Since 1988, EPA has provided over $90 million to region  III states (Maryland, Virginia, District of Columbia, Pennsylvania, Delaware and West Virginia) to implement their NPS programs.  Each state is allocated nonpoint  source funds based on a funding allocation system designed by the federal government.  This allocation system, described in EPA grant guidance (see Nonpoint  Source Program & Grant Guidance For Fiscal Year 1997 and Future Years) is based on a variety of factors, including a state's population, total cropland, pastureland  and rangeland acreage, mining activities and critical aquatic habitat.       In October 1997, during the 25th anniversary of the Clean Water Act, Vice President Gore called for a renewed effort to restore and protect water quality.    The Vice President asked that the Secretary of Agriculture and the Administrator of the EPA work with other affected agencies and develop a Clean Water Action  Plan that builds on clean water successes and addresses three major goals:        enhanced protection from public health threats posed by water pollution;       more effective control of polluted runoff; and       promotion of water quality protection on a watershed basis.          With development of the Clean Water Action Plan, there came additional (incremental) grant funds for selected states.  On October 21, 1998, the President signed the  1999 appropriations bill for EPA to allocate $200 million for states to implement their nonpoint source management programs under Section 319 of the Clean Water Act.    This appropriation provided a major increase of funds for states to make significant progress in resolving their remaining water quality problems.   During FFY 1998 Maryland  received approximately $1.3 million for nonpoint source projects.   As a result of the Clean Water Action Plan, Maryland's 1999 appropriation rose to approximately $2.7 million.
